article.title: Domain Model
article.para: When you click around in the application and find everything working, you will recognize that most of our requirements are already met by the application:

listitem.para: You are able to create owners of pets
You are able to add and edit their pets
You are able to add visits for the owners

article.para: The only thing that is really missing from the requirements is the ability to assign visits to vets. In this chapter we are going to realize this.

section.title: Modifying the Domain Model
section.para: The base-class of all our entities is BaseEntity (in src/main/java/org/springframework/samples/petclinic/model/BaseEntity.java). For proper object-handling we add two methods here: equals and hashCode.
Add
Now we can modify our model to reflect the relation between visits and vets. We add the following code to the file Visit.java (in src/main/java/org/springframework/samples/petclinic/)

Since we don't know how many visits a vet may have (that may be many), we don't want to model the relation between vets and visits bidirectional. Instead we add a method to the ClinicService interface to retrieve all visits of a specified vet. So it is easy to implement filtering or lazy loading of visits later.
Add the following code to the ClinicService interface (in ClinicService.java, which is in src/main/java/org/springframework/samples/petclinic/service/).
section.programlisting: /** * Retrieve Visits from the data store, * returning all visits at a given vet. * @param vet the visited vet * @return a Collection of matching Visits * (or an empty Collection if none found) */ Collection findVisits(Vet vet) throws DataAccessException;
